body: I don’t like this. I think it would reinforce the mob mentality, since people would be able to make decisions based upon if “the mob” likes it or not. If Ruqqus aims to be a platform for free discussion and exchange of ideas it should force people to make decisions based upon the actual ideas presented and not what the hive mind thinks. Even the upvote counter kind of goes against this, but it’s something I can live with.

body: I don’t understand your point. The scale to which people disagree should not matter. People should form their own opinions, not just blindly follow the opinions of others. You will still be able to see the disagreement by looking at the comments, but the key difference is that you’ll be given a *reason*. Just showing the numbers encourages blindly following the majority.
body_html: I don’t understand your point. The scale to which people disagree should not matter. People should form their own opinions, not just blindly follow the opinions of others. You will still be able to see the disagreement by looking at the comments, but the key difference is that you’ll be given a reason. Just showing the numbers encourages blindly following the majority.

body: I'm in favor of what another poster suggested, which was to get rid of up/down in favor of interesting, funny, good point, etc. The score of which you see if you want to sort by "rank" could be total score off all reactions or we could even choose to sort on interesting, funny, etc. based on what we want to see.
body_html: I'm in favor of what another poster suggested, which was to get rid of up/down in favor of interesting, funny, good point, etc. The score of which you see if you want to sort by "rank" could be total score off all reactions or we could even choose to sort on interesting, funny, etc. based on what we want to see.

body:
Pop-up text on a hover would solve that.   Likewise, the up/down numbers could be hidden by default but enabled by users who consider it important.  

As UIs go, this one is not that crowded.  Personally, I'd much rather devote space to up/down votes rather than eighty types of post awards, which also has been suggested.
body_html:
Pop-up text on a hover would solve that. Likewise, the up/down numbers could be hidden by default but enabled by users who consider it important.

As UIs go, this one is not that crowded. Personally, I'd much rather devote space to up/down votes rather than eighty types of post awards, which also has been suggested.

parent.body: I don’t like this. I think it would reinforce the mob mentality, since people would be able to make decisions based upon if “the mob” likes it or not. If Ruqqus aims to be a platform for free discussion and exchange of ideas it should force people to make decisions based upon the actual ideas presented and not what the hive mind thinks. Even the upvote counter kind of goes against this, but it’s something I can live with.
parent.body_html: I don’t like this. I think it would reinforce the mob mentality, since people would be able to make decisions based upon if “the mob” likes it or not. If Ruqqus aims to be a platform for free discussion and exchange of ideas it should force people to make decisions based upon the actual ideas presented and not what the hive mind thinks. Even the upvote counter kind of goes against this, but it’s something I can live with.

parent.body: I don’t understand your point. The scale to which people disagree should not matter. People should form their own opinions, not just blindly follow the opinions of others. You will still be able to see the disagreement by looking at the comments, but the key difference is that you’ll be given a *reason*. Just showing the numbers encourages blindly following the majority.
parent.body_html: I don’t understand your point. The scale to which people disagree should not matter. People should form their own opinions, not just blindly follow the opinions of others. You will still be able to see the disagreement by looking at the comments, but the key difference is that you’ll be given a reason. Just showing the numbers encourages blindly following the majority.

body:
I disagree with this sentiment. Dislike buttons often instigate mob mentality. For example, on YouTube if you want to say something controversial it would be met with huge amounts of dislikes. If someone who disagrees with a video sees the amount of dislikes, it will help reinforce their belief even more, and might lead them to consider the video less. This re-reinforces the hive mind.

Saidit decided to not have dislikes/downvotes off the bat. The advantage of this (in my opinion) is that you can voice a controversial opinion without being down-voted into oblivion. It goes against the hive mind.
body_html:
I disagree with this sentiment. Dislike buttons often instigate mob mentality. For example, on YouTube if you want to say something controversial it would be met with huge amounts of dislikes. If someone who disagrees with a video sees the amount of dislikes, it will help reinforce their belief even more, and might lead them to consider the video less. This re-reinforces the hive mind.

Saidit decided to not have dislikes/downvotes off the bat. The advantage of this (in my opinion) is that you can voice a controversial opinion without being down-voted into oblivion. It goes against the hive mind.

body:
I don't think we need the third bar (one that combines likes and dislikes), as you can just do some mathematics to calculate that yourself. (Just subtract the dislikes from the likes). 

So all that needs to be shown is the number of up votes and the number of down votes. Just one number needs to be added.
body_html:
I don't think we need the third bar (one that combines likes and dislikes), as you can just do some mathematics to calculate that yourself. (Just subtract the dislikes from the likes).

So all that needs to be shown is the number of up votes and the number of down votes. Just one number needs to be added.
